qas.question: What are two types of phagocytes that travel through the body to find invading pathogens?
What are the most abundant kind of phagocyte?
What percentage of leukocytes do neutrophils represent?
What is the process in which neutrophils move towards the site of inflammation called?
What is a regulatory factor produced by macrophages?
What are pathogens that travel through the body looking for phagocytes called?
What is the least abundant type of phagocyte?
What are usually the last cells to arrive at the scene of an infection?
What cell is unable to act as a scavenger?

context: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Neutrophils and macrophages<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> are phagocytes that travel throughout the body in pursuit of invading pathogens. <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b7_0>Neutrophils<b7_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> are normally found in the <b6_0>bloodstream<b6_0/> and are the most abundant type of phagocyte, normally representing <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>50% to 60%<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> of the total circulating leukocytes. During the acute phase of inflammation, particularly as a result of bacterial infection, <b8_0>neutrophils<b8_0/> migrate toward the site of inflammation in a process called <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>chemotaxis<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, and are usually the first cells to arrive at the scene of infection. Macrophages are versatile cells that reside within tissues and produce a wide array of chemicals including enzymes, complement proteins, and regulatory factors such as <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>interleukin 1<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>. <b9_0>Macrophages<b9_0/> also act as scavengers, ridding the body of worn-out cells and other debris, and as antigen-presenting cells that activate the adaptive immune system.
